017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
020import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
021import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools;
023
024/**
025 * Various utility methods for working with colors encoded as packed floats in any of the formats this can use.
026 * <br>
027 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 12/2/2019.
028 */
029public class FloatColors {
030
031    /**
032     * Converts a packed float in HSLA format (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha) to a packed float in RGBA format.
033     * @param hsla an HSLA-format packed float
034     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
035     */
036    public static float hsl2rgb(final float hsla) {
037        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(hsla);
038        return hsl2rgb((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
039    }
040
041    /**
042     * Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.
043     * @param h hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
044     * @param s saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
045     * @param l lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
046     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
047     * @return an RGBA-format packed float
048     */
049    public static float hsl2rgb(final float h, final float s, final float l, final float a){
050        float x = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(h * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
051        float y = h + (2f / 3f);
052        float z = h + (1f / 3f);
053        y -= (int)y;
054        z -= (int)z;
055        y = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(y * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
056        z = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(z * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
057        float v = (l + s * Math.min(l, 1f - l));
058        float d = 2f * (1f - l / (v + 1e-10f));
059        v *= 255f;
060        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
061                (int)(a * 127f) << 25
062                        | (int)(v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, z, d)) << 16
063                        | (int)(v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, y, d)) << 8
064                        | (int)(v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, x, d))
065        );
066    }
067    /**
068     * Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to RGBA and assigns them into changing.
069     * @param changing a non-null Color that will be modified
070     * @param h hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
071     * @param s saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
072     * @param l lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
073     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
074     * @return changing, after assignment
075     */
076    public static Color hslColor(Color changing, final float h, final float s, final float l, final float a){
077        float x = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(h * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
078        float y = h + (2f / 3f);
079        float z = h + (1f / 3f);
080        y -= (int)y;
081        z -= (int)z;
082        y = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(y * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
083        z = Math.min(Math.max(Math.abs(z * 6f - 3f) - 1f, 0f), 1f);
084        float v = (l + s * Math.min(l, 1f - l));
085        float d = 2f * (1f - l / (v + 1e-10f));
086        changing.set(v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, x, d), v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, y, d), v * MathUtils.lerp(1f, z, d), a);
087        return changing;
088    }
089
090    /**
091     * Converts a packed float in RGBA format to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha),
092     * which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for conversions.
093     * @param rgba an RGBA-format packed float
094     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
095     */
096    public static float rgb2hsl(final float rgba) {
097        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(rgba);
098        return rgb2hsl((decoded & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f, (decoded >>> 24 & 0xFE) / 255f);
099    }
100
101    /**
102     * Converts the four RGBA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in "HSLA format" (hue,
103     * saturation, lightness, alpha), which isn't one of the regular formats this supports but can be useful for
104     * conversions.
105     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0
106     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0
107     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0
108     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
109     * @return an "HSLA-format" packed float
110     */
111    public static float rgb2hsl(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
112        float x, y, z, w;
113        if(g < b) {
114            x = b;
115            y = g;
116            z = -1f;
117            w = 2f / 3f;
118        }
119        else {
120            x = g;
121            y = b;
122            z = 0f;
123            w = -1f / 3f;
124        }
125        if(r < x) {
126            z = w;
127            w = r;
128        }
129        else {
130            w = x;
131            x = r;
132        }
133        float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
134        float l = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
135        return Color.toFloatBits(Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)), (x - l) / (Math.min(l, 1f - l) + 1e-10f), l, a);
136    }
137
138
139    /**
140     * Given a color stored as a packed float and an alpha multiplier to affect that color (between 0f and 1f, inclusive
141     * and clamped in that range), this makes a packed float color that has the same red, green, and blue channels but
142     * has its own alpha multiplied by {@code alpha}, without constructing any objects along the way. If you want to set
143     * the alpha without considering its current value, you can use {@link #setAlpha(float, float)}
144     *
145     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
146     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
147     * @param alpha  between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to multiply the color's own alpha by
148     * @return a color encoded as a packed float, using color's RGB channels but with its A channel times {@code alpha}
149     */
150    public static float multiplyAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
151        final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor);
152        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(bits & 0xFFFFFF
153                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) ((bits >>> 24) * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
154    }
155
156    /**
157     * Given a color stored as a packed float, and a desired alpha to set for that color (between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive
158     * and clamped in that range), this makes a new float that has the same red, green, and blue channels but has been
159     * set to the given alpha, without constructing any objects along the way. This does not consider the current alpha
160     * of the encoded color; if you want to do that, you can use {@link #multiplyAlpha(float, float)}.
161     *
162     * @param encodedColor a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
163     *                     or {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
164     * @param alpha        between 0.0 and 1.0 inclusive, the alpha to set into the returned packed color
165     * @return another color encoded as a packed float, using encodedColor's RGB channels and the given alpha
166     */
167    public static float setAlpha(final float encodedColor, final float alpha) {
168        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encodedColor) & 0xFFFFFF
169                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (255f * alpha), 0), 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
170    }
171
172    /**
173     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
174     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} or
175     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be
176     * between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both
177     * could be produced using Oklab, both could be produced using IPT, or both could be libGDX-native RGB, but they
178     * can't mix. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
179     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
180     * @param end the target color as a packed float
181     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
182     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
183     */
184    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
185        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
186                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
187                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
188        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
189                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
190                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
191                | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
192    }
193
194    /**
195     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
196     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
197     * as from {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} or
198     * {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
199     * end). Both start and end should use the same color space; that is, both could be produced using IPT_HQ, or both
200     * could be produced using YCwCm, but not a mix of the two. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
201     * Colors.
202     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
203     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
204     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
205     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
206     */
207    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
208        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
209                ys = (s & 0xFF), cws = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, cms = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s & 0xFE000000,
210                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF;
211        change *= (e >>> 25) * 0.007874016f;
212        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + change * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
213                | (((int) (cws + change * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
214                | (((int) (cms + change * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
215                | as);
216    }
217
218    /**
219     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
220     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
221     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
222     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
223     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
224     */
225    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
226        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
227    }
228
229    /**
230     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
231     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
232     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
233     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
234     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
235     */
236    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
237        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
238    }
239
240    /**
241     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
242     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
243     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
244     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
245     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
246     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
247     */
248    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
249        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
250    }
251
252    /**
253     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
254     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
255     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
256     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
257     */
258    public static float mix(float... colors) {
259        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
260            return 0f; // transparent, usually
261        float result = colors[0];
262        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
263            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
264        }
265        return result;
266    }
267
268    /**
269     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
270     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
271     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.utils.FloatArray}, using its {@code items}
272     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
273     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
274     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
275     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
276     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
277     */
278    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
279        final int end = offset + size;
280        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
281            return 0f; // transparent, usually
282        float result = colors[offset];
283        for (int i = offset + 1, denom = 2; i < end; i++, denom++) {
284            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
285        }
286        return result;
287    }
288
289    /**
290     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of varargs of alternating floats
291     * representing colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}.
292     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
293     * @param colors an array or varargs that should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
294     * @return a mix of all colors given respecting their weights, as a packed float color
295     */
296    public static float unevenMix(float... colors) {
297        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0) return 0f;
298        if(colors.length <= 2) return colors[0];
299        return unevenMix(colors, 0, colors.length);
300    }
301
302    /**
303     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating floats representing
304     * colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}, starting at {@code offset} in the array and
305     * continuing for {@code size} indices in the array. The {@code size} should be an even number 2 or greater,
306     * otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative finite float values; this method handles
307     * normalizing them internally.
308     * @param colors starting at {@code offset}, this should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
309     * @param offset where to start reading from in {@code colors}
310     * @param size how many indices to read from {@code colors}; must be an even number
311     * @return the mixed color, as a packed float in the same color space as the given float colors
312     */
313    public static float unevenMix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
314        size &= -2;
315        final int end = offset + size;
316        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
317            return 0f; // transparent, usually
318        float result = colors[offset];
319        float current = colors[offset + 1], total = current;
320        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
321            total += colors[i];
322        }
323        total = 1f / total;
324        current *= total;
325        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
326            float mixColor = colors[i-1], weight = colors[i] * total;
327            result = lerpFloatColors(result, mixColor, weight / (current += weight));
328        }
329        return result;
330    }
331}
